[h3]Masterpiece[/h3]

Of all the gaming companies today, Rockstar is the only one that can achieve such a high level of elaboration in absolutely everything present in their games. The open world, graphics, atmosphere, story, gameplay, little details ‚Äì all of these are executed at the highest level. And Red Dead Redemption 2 is no exception.

When you start up RDR 2, the game greets the player with a lengthy prologue. It immediately shows the player the pace at which most of the game will unfold. A deliberate and meditative pace is the hallmark of Red Dead Redemption 2. All animations in the game are meticulously crafted; Arthur slowly opens cabinets, slowly picks up items, etc. All of this allows you to savor every moment in the game.

To date, this is the most atmospheric and authentic game I have ever played. Besides the animations, the following elements greatly contribute to the immersion:

1. Graphics. The game is already 7 years old, and it still looks better than many modern AAA titles. Countless times I've stopped at the edge of a mountain or a hill to take in the picturesque views of this game's world. Indescribable beauty!
2. Sound Design. The clopping of horse hooves, the singing of birds, the sounds of towns, etc. All the sounds are executed at the highest level.

And I'd like to separately highlight another point. I've never seen such a living, breathing open world anywhere else. The immense diversity of the animal kingdom (so alive that rabbits run right under your horse xD), the NPCs have their own daily schedules. They can be building a house, which, after some in-game time, will actually be completed. The world lives on without the player's involvement, and you can feel it.

But the most prominent feature of the game's world is the random events. The small quests you stumble upon while riding to some mission. The game naturally presents this content to you. You're just trotting along the road and see a column of smoke from a campfire in the distance. It might be an enemy gang, or it could be two guys distilling moonshine, and there are tons of different situations like that. Because of this, I only started using fast travel around the 80-hour mark (and even then, only for long distances), because I didn't want to miss this content.

I won't talk much about the story, as it's straightforward. It's ABSOLUTE CINEMA. The direction, acting, staging, story development, characters, dialogues ‚Äì everything is executed at an incredible level. The story of Arthur Morgan and the Van der Linde gang will leave no one indifferent. And through the side quests, you become even more attached to Arthur and his story. In general, Arthur is one of the best protagonists in the gaming industry.

When you fully settle into the game's rhythm, immerse yourself in its atmosphere, and get into the flow, you're no longer playing a game; you're living the life of Arthur Morgan.

I understand that RDR 2 isn't for everyone. This kind of meditative gameplay might be tedious or boring for some. Nevertheless, I highly recommend giving this game a try, absolutely to everyone.

Red Dead Redemption 2... Took me 7 years to finally get around to playing this. And I can say with confidence, I waited way too long.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is an accurate title for what the game is about. Blood, death and redemption. It's a game that comes with depth. A story about a man who realizes that loyalty isn't worth it, if it's for a man blinded by greed. From characters that have a world of history to them, to the environment that takes place 30 years after the American civil war. The story makes the characters feel real and with that realness, it makes the player care about them. A rare thing to be able to pull off with a game, from my experience. Happy little moments, twists and turns and soul crushing conclusions. This game has it all.

The gameplay comes down to riding horses, doing a bit of gunslinging and making choices that shape out  who you are and how the game will eventually conclude. Though that's only the main part. The game is an open world one, meaning there's a lot of ground to explore, animals to hunt, people to run into and random oddities to find. You're free to explore the world without time limits, which is big bonus, due to the unhurried feel it brings to the game. Just remember to bring the right kind of equipment for the different environments. Wouldn't want to freeze to death after all.

Along with the characters and the world, the music also grows with you (Or it did for me anyways). I started off not really liking it and not really listening to it. Towards the end of the game however, I started listening to both the lyrics and the music itself. Turns out, Rockstar knew what they were doing. Most of the time, if not always, the music in the game fits what's happening in the story at each moment. Powerful vocal, distorted guitar riffs and American Venom. They cooked. Most likely another reason why so many people got hit so hard by the conclusion at the end.

Now this being a Rockstar game, it doesn't come without its issues. The main one on pc being the memory leak issues. The longer you play the game, the more dedicated GPU memory it uses. If it uses all of it, the game crashes. Thankfully it goes up relatively slowly, but regardless, it limits the playtime according to the player's GPU. The only fix being to close the game and restart it. Other than the memory leak issues, I had trouble with the horses not going where I wanted them to, even when there was plenty of space in a gap between trees or rocks. Some other small glitches included characters not really sitting in the right spots (Uncle partly inside a box), the usual clipping and the player character falling over, when hitching the horse at Blackwater. Some black screen flashing does also happen, but more in borderless windowed mode, than in fullscreen mode.

Overall, this game is really fucking good. It's long, but there's zero reason to hurry with it. If you want to just spend days hunting, go for it. If you want to explore the world, you're free to do so, though make sure you aren't wanted by the law. If you want to just do the story, that also works, but you'll miss quite a few interesting characters. It took me 65 hours to finish the main story, but if I tried to do everything else, it would be closer 120 hours. I liked the characters, the story, the environment, the attention to detail, the gameplay and the music.

So with that and the bugs in mind, this game is a strong 9/10 for me. I absolutely recommend this to anyone who wants experience the wild west along with a very impactful story and one of the best main characters I've ever had the pleasure of playing as. 

Thank you Rockstar, for this incredible experience.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is a unique game that stands out in many ways, from its story to the most minute details that Rockstar incorporated into its development.
But I think where it really shines is in its protagonist, Arthur Morgan: what begins as a simple outlaw with an odd yet straightforward way of seeing the world ruthless, grumpy, and dangerous, yet loyal to those who share his lifestyle will ultimately become one of the most moving and profound stories I‚Äôve ever seen in a video game, or even, I dare say, in the Western genre, not just in video games but in any other medium.

The Old West is a genre that has been explored even outside of video games, and in doing so we‚Äôve come to know various characters shaped by the stories told. Among them, Arthur Morgan stands out because, despite starting out as just another simple character, he makes us reflect on the problems of the past and the present. The virtue of his character lies in his development: he goes from being a flat, one-dimensional outlaw with only a few significant personality traits to an Arthur who is finally able to think for himself and try to atone for the mistakes his past forced him to commit. As a result, even when we‚Äôre no longer playing, memories of the magnificent adventure we shared with him come flooding back.

The game was released at one of the best possible moments to highlight its story, values, and lessons; after several years of series and films that told the stories of notorious criminals pragmatizing their actions and leading consumers to glorify them, a phenomenon that occurs across all cultural media and even in society what stood out was the history of great criminals of the past. What was intended as an effort to show viewers their most atrocious acts and their evil instead became, for most, a tribute and glorification of their figures.

At the start of the game, it seemed like it was making the same mistake as that supposed golden age of the Wild West, showcasing its complicated exploits and how impressive and dangerous they were, but in the end it turns out to be a critique of the lifestyle of those outlaws and, above all, of the glorification of that era by American society and the best way to see this is thru Arthur Morgan.

Arthur is the kind of protagonist who‚Äôs hard to see as the sidekick to the plan‚Äôs mastermind or as the one around whom the plot revolves, because he‚Äôs the perfect helper you‚Äôd want as a follower cruel, ruthless, and efficient, yet still loyal to the gang and to his family. Despite all those threats, Arthur doesn‚Äôt do it out of personal pleasure or because he‚Äôs a sadist who enjoys pain; he does it to help those he considers his family, more specifically the Van der Linde gang.

I recommend the game not just because I like it. I recommend it because, the entire plot, its Historical accuracy is one of the things the game can be praised for, not only showing us how most old western movies glorify that era, but also showing us parts that are not usually explored in depth in these reproductions, showing us not just one side or the other but showing its nuances and the historical temporal context.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is one of those rare games that doesn‚Äôt just entertain you ‚Äî it absorbs you, pulls you into its world, and makes you feel like you‚Äôre genuinely living someone else‚Äôs life. A lot of games try to balance great gameplay with a meaningful story, but RDR2 is the only one I‚Äôve played where both come together so naturally that you almost forget where the gameplay ends and the storytelling begins. And honestly, it‚Äôs the only game that has ever made me emotional in a real, unexpected way.

Right from the start, the game proves it‚Äôs built differently. The world doesn‚Äôt beg for your attention or force non-stop action on you. Instead, it invites you to settle into its rhythm ‚Äî a slower, more grounded pace that fits the late 1800s perfectly. Riding through snowy mountains, dense forests, open plains, or muddy towns feels like an experience on its own. The gameplay doesn‚Äôt rush you, and that‚Äôs part of its magic. You‚Äôre given room to breathe, to explore, and to connect with the world at your own speed.

The mechanics themselves feel deliberately designed to match the setting. Gunfights are weighty and intense, horses actually feel like living animals instead of vehicles, and simple actions like looting or cooking take a moment. Some players might call these little things ‚Äúslow,‚Äù but honestly, they‚Äôre tiny complaints compared to what they add to the experience. These slower details ground the game and make it feel real ‚Äî not just another fast-paced action title. You‚Äôre not supposed to fly through the world; you‚Äôre supposed to live in it.

What separates Red Dead Redemption 2 from most games is the way it builds your connection to the character you play. Instead of dumping exposition on you, it lets you learn about him through the way he interacts with the world. The honor system, the conversations, the choices you make on the road, and even the quiet moments when you‚Äôre doing absolutely nothing ‚Äî they all paint a picture of who he is and who he might become. You start to understand him on a level that‚Äôs incredibly rare in video games.

And then there‚Äôs the cast around you. RDR2 has some of the most believable, well-written characters I‚Äôve ever seen in a game. These aren‚Äôt just NPCs who exist to give you missions; they feel like an actual group of people with their own personalities, priorities, and histories. You‚Äôll hear them chatting around campfires, arguing about something that happened earlier, or just joking around as you walk by. Little details like that make them feel real, and before you even realize it, you start caring about them.

That‚Äôs where the emotional side of the game hits hardest ‚Äî not in one dramatic moment, but in the gradual, natural way you become attached to the people and world around you. It sneaks up on you. One hour you‚Äôre hunting or playing poker or getting into trouble in town, and the next you‚Äôre suddenly hit with a feeling you weren‚Äôt expecting. For me, it was the first game that genuinely made me emotional. Not because of some forced tearjerker moment, but because I truly felt connected to the character I was playing and the life he was living.

The world itself deserves just as much praise as the story. This isn‚Äôt an open world full of empty space or repetitive tasks. Every area feels handcrafted, full of things to discover. You can spend hours hunting legendary animals, fishing in a quiet lake, stumbling into strange encounters on the trail, or just riding across fields as the sun sets. Even when you‚Äôre doing ‚Äúnothing,‚Äù it feels meaningful. The world feels alive in a way that almost no other game has pulled off.

If I had to point out flaws, they‚Äôre honestly tiny compared to what the game achieves. The movement can feel a bit heavy at times, and fast travel isn‚Äôt instantly available everywhere. But in a weird way, even those minor inconveniences add to the authenticity. RDR2 is a game that wants you to slow down and experience its world the way it was meant to be experienced. And once you embrace that, it‚Äôs hard to imagine it working any other way.

What makes Red Dead Redemption 2 the best story-driven game ever made is how everything works together ‚Äî the gameplay, the world, the pacing, the characters, the writing ‚Äî all of it. Nothing feels out of place or forced. You‚Äôre not just watching a story unfold; you‚Äôre shaping it. You‚Äôre living it. And by the time the credits roll, you realize you‚Äôve gone through something bigger than a typical video game.

For me, that‚Äôs why RDR2 stands above everything else: it‚Äôs the only game that‚Äôs ever made me feel something that lingered long after I put the controller down. Video Games have been a form of art and medium of entertainment for different generations in the past few decades, constantly growing and expanding on different forms of game mechanics, graphical design, audio visual experiences, and much more. Red Dead Redemption 2 is a successor in all of these categories and more providing a profound experience that doesn't feel like normal gameplay. This game delivers on a story that, through your own morality and ethics, questions not just your choices as Arthur the protagonist, but also as yourself.

RDR2 does an excellent job at placing you in Arthur's perspective as you are left wondering what had happened to the gang to end up in the following chapters as well as the true nature of these characters as their past actions catch up to them. You are left in control of a character struggling with coming to terms with his actions both in past and present while actively not fully being able to control them, as if even though you play this character he is still his own man and you are just the controller.

What RDR2 excels at the most is creating a compelling story that will leave you wondering, for better or for worse, what redemption really means. Is redemption and all that ensues a salvation from a previous violent past? Or is redemption a change of character in it's own right? Maybe all or none, but most certainly it is what you make of it. RDR2 is exactly that as well, a work of art where best commonly said "beauty is in the eye of the beholder". Maybe Arthur is capable of redeeming his past with the time spent in these chapters. Then again maybe not, but at the end of the day, you feel compelled to do everything you can to change the past for better or for worse. 

This game delivers excellently on challenging the player's own emotions on empathy, and the perspective of violence, life, and death shifting violently and rapidly as the story progresses. RDR2 is not just a game that you play, it is a story that you experience and with experiences like this it's hard to not take some of it with you for the rest of your life.

TL;DR: The game gave me freedom everywhere except where it mattered most ‚Äî the story ‚Äî and the cinematic tropes (especially standoffs) made the narrative feel artificial instead of meaningful. No wonder it is 50% cheaper on a discount than its predecessor! If you really want this title, buy it on a discount, it happens relatively often.

NOTE: Played on Linux Mint with RTX 3070 and runs flawlessly.

This review includes SPOILERS!

I went into this game blind, not knowing anything about the Red Dead series and only being influenced by the fame, how well received the game is and how many copies have sold. People are praising left and right how amazing RPG this is and I realize that this is not an RPG but an action adventure on rails since the player has no agency at all. But it gets worse: this game which is sold as a sequel to the Red Dead Redemption 1(RDR1) is actually a prequel to RDR1 with the main goal to portray the downfall of Van Der Linde‚Äôs gang. For this purpose, game introduces a disposable character Arthur Morgan who can‚Äôt do anything about it because the script says so and then to make it worse, game makes Arthur‚Äôs death meaningless by introducing not one but 2 (two) epilogues in which player plays as John who is a protagonist of the RDR1. These 2 epilogues are actually a prologue for RDR1. Who thought that this is a good idea? But it gets worse! The game has 6 acts in which the player plays as Arthur but 5 acts are artificially stretched and repeatable ongoing motifs, while the actual story of RDR2 happens in act 6! And that is also not enough but the technical brilliance of the game kills off the story. The game has all the tools implemented for extended cowboy fantasy where the player could have had his own gang, or build a ranch, farming/ranching, crafting, missions - all irrelevant because these things don‚Äôt change anything in the game. Later I found out that John is conditioned by the law in RDR1 to hunt down Dutch Van Der Linde, which he manages yet John is being tricked and his son Jack decides to go on a revenge hunt. So‚Ä¶ why doesn't RDR2 follow the story of Jack instead of creating this prequel with disposable characters? Because, I must say, someone in Rock Star is rather incompetent to think how an amazing foundation can be used for a good story. So to sum up, Arthur as a character for 6 acts is a disposable irrelevant character. The game revolves around Dutch and his idiotic decisions, showing off how fake his ‚Äúcare about the people is‚Äù when several gang members die and Dutch himself leaves some gang members hanging when he could clearly help. To make it even more shallow, some gang members were killed and their corpse presented in a trope dramatic way yet it makes no impact as I don‚Äôt have any appreciation for those characters - one was killed offscreen delivered as a mounted corpse on a horse and everyone in the gang were shocked and distressed for losing a gang member, while I am like ‚ÄúWho?‚Äù. Even now I can‚Äôt remember the name of that character. And Dutch, always saying the same story like a broken record ‚ÄúWe just need more money‚Äù and then proceeds to do the most idiotic thing that puts the whole gang in greater danger in each act. And then he talks about sailing to faraway places not knowing how far these places might be. Micah Bell is the main antagonist of the game and as soon as the player finds him, it is clear as day that he is trouble and very soon, again, it is clear as day that he is a psychopath. And even Arthur sees that he is both trouble and a psychopath and there is no option to address that. 

The epilogues are something else. First of all I was just confused: why am I playing as John now? It makes no impact at all since Arthur didn‚Äôt have that many interactions through 5 long acts with him that makes it important to the player. This is when I looked up for answers online and realised that this game is a prequel and not a sequel. This was supposed to be some story for the fans of RDR1 I guess but it makes no sense since this is a sequel. Then the story sort of starts anew and then I have realized just how wrong this all was! This could have been Arthur! The mechanics are there already! Arthur could have splitted from the gang and fighting Dutch for independence. Or helping the local community (as clearly it is demonstrated by this mechanic when John works on a farm for David Geddes)! And then some sources on the internet point out that this was supposed to be possible but it is cut! This was supposed to be done by Arthur! And instead - we have an overextended repetitive story (Dutch needs more money and has a plan) that can not be changed because in their ‚Äúinfinitive wisdom‚Äù this is a prequel and in RDR1 and Arthur is never mentioned by anyone in RDR1 so it had to be on rails. And then there are these standoffs, I believe they are called Mexican Standoffs where everyone points a gun at everyone and waits for someone to blink. A Holywood invention that is so fake and does not make dramatic tension in games at all. The worst one is the one at the end when Sadie Adler gets John and Charles to hunt Micah. First of all John feels changed by then and it is out of character for him to go on a hunt. Then in the final confrontation, while Micah has John under fire, Sadie who came to kill Micah, points a gun at him and doesn‚Äôt shoot. Instant barf. This is so out of her character at that time. So Micah uses the situation in his favour, keeps her at the gunpoint and threatens John and out of nowhere Dutch appears and we have this standoff. And Dutch kills Micah! So not even that satisfaction is given to the player! Dutch could have killed John and then Micah and still he would have had an upper hand! This is so out of character. And then he leaves literally and leaves gold and money behind for John to take! Dutch‚Ä¶ leaves money‚Ä¶ the only thing he ever wanted and valued. These characters are so one dimensional and shallow.

This could have been an amazing game. Players could have had choices, technology and mechanics are there but it only hurts the game. Why not Jack‚Äôs story arch with all this tech and possibilities? This story of RDR2 should never have been a game! This should be a bit shorter as a movie or a TV show since everything is on rails.


And then a lot of players tell me a story about how amazing this game is, how the story is and so on. It doesn‚Äôt give freedom as some point out, but restriction unless they never wanted to play the quests, which might be. Well, according to Achievements on Steam, at the time of writing of this review, only 20% of players finished Epilogue part 2. In fact, completion of chapters falls off as many RPGs so it is not special in that regard. It is not a big percentage of those who play online either, it‚Äôs around 30%. It is a waste of potential and a waste of time as the game doesn‚Äôt revolve around the player at all. It could have been an unprecedented cowboy experience, instead it tries to be a tragic drama with no impact infested with repetitive motifs and tediousness. 

Technically it is extremely well optimized - something that most modern game studios don‚Äôt do. Because of it, it looks really well even on older hardware. I just had very few visual glitches, none of them were game breaking (i.e. light sphere displayed in a cutscene instead of being rendered as an actual light). Also, controller support is ok. It's just weird when the context menu does not appear when it should cause frustration in certain moments. Game menus are horrible! Organization and unnecessary sub - menus are such a drag - I hate it. And then, some features are not displayed in the player stats (like how positive or negative a player's character is, instead it is briefly visible when a player does a good or bad deed). Also, the fact that the player can not save the game once the quest starts and it is quite frustrating especially during the epilogues.

What a shame.
